newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian stocks mixed, market to remain bullish.
newsitem.headline: Croatian stocks mixed, market to remain bullish.

text.p: Croatian stocks traded mixed on Wednesday, with mild gains among blue chips and traders said the market would remain bullish for some time to come.
"Demand for Istrian hoteliers is quite strong at the moment and they are on the rise," a trader at the I.F.C. brokerage and consultancy said.
He added their growth could be ascribed to speculation about their foreign share placement and participation of foreign investors.
He also predicted new gains for confectioner Kras, and a possible period of stagnation for drugs firm Pliva and Zagrebacka Banka, in line with developments in London.
* Of 13 active issues, seven rose, three fell and three were flat.
* Most actively traded Zagrebacka edged up five kuna to close at 1,005 with 5,108 shares changing hands.
* Another fully listed stock Pliva traded flat at 13,000 kuna throughout the session, on volume of 183 shares.
* Istrian hoteliers were the biggest gainers:
- Riviera climbed 60 kuna to 165, on volume of 724 shares.
- Arenaturist jumped 44 kuna to 150, with 1,228 units sold.
- Jadranturist was up 30 kuna to 370, trading 595 shares.
- Laguna edged up 10 kuna to 930 after peaking at 950 kuna during the session, on volume of 151 units.
* Kras continued its steady climb, adding 20 kuna to 620 with 1,868 units sold.
* Food processor Podravka was up four kuna to 274 with 1,624 shares changing hands.
* Tour operator Atlas was the biggest loser, down 45 kuna to 150 from late in August with 63 shares sold.
* Another hotelier Suncani Hvar lost one kuna to 22, trading 424 shares.
* Cable-maker Elka edged down four kuna to 191, with 116 shares sold.
* Hotelier Zlatni rat was flat at 110 kuna, with 23 shares traded.
* Karlovacka Pivovara brewery remained unchanged at 195 kuna, selling 107 units.
* First issue of public debt refinancing bonds traded at 96.86 percent of face value, after recent coupon and interest payment, on turnover of 17.2 million kuna.
* The second tranche edged up to 4.35 from 4.34 percent above par, on turnover of 16.6 million kuna.
* Daily share volume down at 12,214, total turnover including bonds slighlty lower at 43.4 million kuna.
* Central bank's exchange rate: 5.4317 kuna = $1. -- Laura Lui, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
